content: There is a lack of innovation in the field of AI agents, with most developments being variations of the original conversational AI models.
Closing the feedback loop for agents is an area with zero innovation, despite its potential to enhance agent autonomy.
Sourcing tasks for agents from systems other than traditional ticket systems is not innovative and can compromise decision-making logs.
Building UIs to manage multiple agents simultaneously is not a novel solution and has been explored previously without significant breakthroughs.
Integrating agents into multi-user chats is useful for personal automations but does not address the fundamental challenges of using agents for software creation.
Storing agent session logs alongside code changes in Git is ineffective because developers are unlikely to review them, similar to how they often don't read all the code.
The biggest obstacle to general agent use is solving the 'lethal trifecta,' which appears to be an undecidable problem for general agents, making current solutions merely superficial.
Many who advocate for 'tokens tokens tokens' publish dysfunctional software or provide inactionable advice.
The author has not learned anything new or interesting from tech discussions in the past year, likening the community to philosophers who lack practical building experience.
